author: Charles White
title: Skin creams with paraffin in them linked to house fire deaths
text:
Creams are there to treat skin condition (Picture: Shutterstock) Eczema and psoriasis creams have been the root cause of several deaths across the country over the last 10 years. 
The creams, such as some made by E45, contain paraffin and have opened people to the risk of setting themselves on fire.
BBC Asian Network apologises after asking 'What is the right punishment for blasphemy?' Medicine regulators are now calling for all creams to contain a warning.
Not changing your sheets or washing your clothes while using the cream can create a serious fire risk as flammable material builds up on the fabric.
The BBC Radio 5 investigation has found 37 deaths in England were linked to skin creams since 2010.
One such cream is popular brand E45 (Picture: E45) Brand manufactures such as E45 will start to warn people from next month after 63-year-old Christopher Holyoake died in 2015.
The Leicester-man’s bedding was covered in flammable residue and when his lighter came into contact he stood little chance of escaping the fire.
Gluten-free diets may actually be doing you more harm than good Other products like Cetraben have been linked to fire deaths.
John Hills, 84, died in a nursing home in Sussex after his pipe came into contact with clothes that had traces of the product in them.
In London 28 deaths were linked to paraffin creams.
The skin creams can come off on clothes and bed sheets (Picture: Getty)  
John Smith, chief executive of the Proprietary Association of Great Britain told the BBC some manufacturers had already put a warning on all paraffin-based creams.
He also insisted that the creams were ‘appropriately safe’.
Metro.co.uk has contacted the makers of the creams.
